Alcoholism 1 (Minqi of A Bathroom——Han Dynsasty)
item.description: Somehow, the mullet breached the sea wall To terrorize the neighborhood with their squelching—— Constantly sucking debris into their maws, And the endemic AC hum isn’t helping. Another night sat illicitly, As the school sought to swallow One half of symmetry. Reflected on the lake within the hollow Was a brightly lit home partitioned by palm. Subtle piano notes sounded about the air, But those frenzied fish disquited the calm—— A thought was inserted: it wasn’t fair That nobody told Narcissus That what he saw was something other.

item.title: Ask The Bugs; They'll Tell You
item.description: They Said: “Well, we’ve been speaking with the moon. She told us to ask you a question… He wants to know if you’re coming home soon. Additionally, we have a suggestion—— She’d like to show you something you’ve never seen before. She’s in her spot and has meticulously marked and set the stage—— Hark! Hence draws desirous drippings; she adds without rancour That you already know who burnt down the house with sage.

item.title: MEYE Space Jam
item.description: D’abord, c’était un bordeaux—— Still tastes the same with rain water, you know? So we sat with wet hair on the misty roof Looking for beautiful horses, looking for proof. “We” knew nothing, but eye had all veracity Of liking this boy who emerged from his mouse hole to walk in the rain; He was tender and sweet, complete with the sagacity Of a serial killer——he showed me his collection of frozen brains.

item.title: A Prayer for Cancer Sun Males
item.description: Lord, in your wisdom you made the rain—— So often a necessary inconvenience; You decided to make the reign (Of A. Spirit, that is) So often a necessary inconvenience. You included mosquitoes and cockroaches in your plan. You set the heavenly bodies in motion—— At times agreeing, At times disagreeing. My God, you created every living and “non-living” thing with purpose; In our iniquity and ignorance before you we are worthless.

item.title: To Grieve What Could Be Called A Compartmented Box
item.description: An empty shell of a former home—— When the ornaments were taken away, we discovered they had maliciously been hiding our dead skin and hair, Our nails from fingers and toes. Shame no one will ever know. And they can wipe and sweep, scrub and scrub, But there are gaps and eaves that we have snuck within, where they will never ever find us. We, amnesiacs hereof, Rest in the cruc’ble of love.

item.description: A diverted interlude, Sheltered in the covet Of a slanted tree, Which ran up to my ankles. Actually, it was two. One which covered half, And the other, Which grew almost parallel To the flowing glass, Before curving up from the bank. He then sloped down and Placed a foot on the riverbed, Completing the aforementioned—— Covet in pavilion style. item.title: It Makes You Age (Sharp 9 Gallery)
That Time at Crawfish Junction When God Got Mad at Me for Naming A Bong After The Angel Metatron Who Isn't Even In The Bible By The Way
item.description: It’s after the end of the world, don’t you know that yet? Since 33, most have believed the Apocalypse would come in their lifetime. It’s probably because when something ends, it is then finished, And finished things will no longer produce novelty. Admittedly, most of this Planet’s novelty is bleak—— How often immense hope is co-opted by the forces of fear To end in failure. So too History must end, But it came before thyme and after singing; In this life it ain’t no Burger Kinging—— When Ol’ John P had his way, the truth we did forget.

item.description: When put on Earth, received all their own Job: So Elihu, with lies disguised as truths, Whose “I am” reaps cogito of Magog, Will come to those whose faith bears rotten fruit. item.title: Before All Ages
item.description: The orbiters gesticulated there; Monorails glided along in silence, While flashing lights indifferently got glares From beams and passengers coldly quiet. Indeed as were his architecture plans To conjure more flimsy wire and concrete, Revealed to me by Trojan and Greek hands, Flanking our Jupiter ninety degrees On both sides. On hexagonal shaped streets Stood I On Saturn, Whose ouroboros rail it wounds round and round; Janus reports on the unseen and Knot ,Which, tied at the planet core, Holds fast us to its revolutions qua time.

item.title: Post Iarus ad Didascalicum
item.description: For free, handing out poems on the street, E’en the reading man disliked my stuff: “When all is black it’s y’all who lack sight’s ability, For nothing has no hues, like sterility.” He suggested a medium treat Meant of all that which I love. The musician who in underemployment wallows, Reveals his enjoyment such as follows: Beauty, though whole, is expressed in privational difference, So I love all poems, even libational limericks.

item.title: Moon-Maybe-McWhirtle
item.description: Mourning dove up above, Her bosom shines on earth; Her haughty full-ish-ness Gone in six days To be seen soon again, Without apology; She has needs, also yours Are here displayed.

item.title: Sun-Pseudo-Sonnet
item.description: She prefers the pool while does lapse my mind Engaged in research of Sir Brother Sun. Does he wake each dawn indignant or kind? If the day is dubious, the knight won. For he does shine and does irradiate A crow and dog sharing some fentanyl With a man a hard earned meal served on plate Stars or shine morality rendered null As all that gives indifferently destroys. Swarming gnats want to know if you can hear Straining echoes of the last dying voice Or tell their dreams from a castrated leer.

item.title: « On The Road »
item.description: One realizes when they go out west. That so many have never seen a real southern belle twink before. A prophet is never recognized is his own home, at best, And so i like to see things I’ve never seen before. The south is so provincial in ways we often forget. Here, it’s a phone booth every couple blocks, most neighborhoods have a community garden, Sundry others which beget, Freedom, but somehow, with such amenities, hearts harden.

item.title: The Magic City - Spoken Word Accompaniment to Sun Ra
Liturgical Violence: A Eulogy for Unwritten Eulogies of Those Who Lost Their Life and Lived
Liturgical Violence: A Euology for Unwritten Eulogies of Those Who Lost Their Life and Lived
item.description: Out of love and out of time, It’s true the last year ought’ve plagued my mind, But I still feel the need to look inside A live mind To find what live there is inside after it already died. Indeed, there were some wheels and satellites still spinning, Even as it looked little like it did before. Whatever game you’ve gleaned to be losing or winning, You’ll find that you you once were is there no more.

item.title: I Know Something's Very Wrong
item.description: “The pulse returns for prodigal suns Who hid themselves in the deep covet of a darkened cloud, Refusing rejoinder for those things thought out loud. And they were cached there of their own selfish wants When four little children began drowning at once. They went untried for their crimes – no one saw them Because rays of light found four bodies at the bottom. And no matter the memories of the secrets stashed there sliced and sewn up, Because the body, Every time, Forgets out of pure frustration At its sensations Anesthetized, While the digits of demons deposit eggs that when grown up Too remember nothing of the host’s consummate constipation.

item.title: Towards The End of Spring, When We All Get Used to Living Again
Towards the End of Spring, When We All Get Used to Living Again
item.description: “Somehow, someway, it all comes alive again, From contingency being grows wings to fly, Always becoming what it might have been, But i get sad when cicadas die. Yes, there are millions of them, and they all look the same. They’re dumb and can’t see very well. They’re loud and can get in the way. But oh, if they don’t sound the much needed bell That the day of judgement has arrived.

item.title: Marsha Linehan (Who Was Diagnosed with Schizophrenia) Talks to Catholic Jesus
item.description: “Amen, I say to you, my Father in heaven created man to be of two natures. He has a Logical Mind and an Emotional Mind. Only when these two balances are brought on the same plane can man live as he was made to. My Father ordained this synthesizing of halves before time, before creation. It was declared thus, The Wise Mind.” “Why won’t you tell me to kill myself, O Lord?

item.title: Warhol's Many Maos
item.description: Tucked away in some gallery of the Columbia Museum of Art, granted by anonymous doner, hangs 20 eyes. I sat in front of this jury for some time as I saw the ignorant regard everything else; they had no idea of these faces’ monetary value. The work is not listed on the museum’s website. Ah, well, what could be said about the people of South Carolina that hasn’t been said already?

item.title: Vultures 0
item.description: After Tolstoy 1 “When my bird was looking at my computer monitor, I thought ‘wooooah, that bird has no idea what he’s looking at.’ And yet, what does the bird do? Does he panic? No, he can’t really panic, he just does the best he can. Is he able to live in a world where he’s so ignorant? Well, he doesn’t really have a choice. Yeah, he can kinda live… usually the bird’s okay, even though he doesn’t understand the world, and he can kinda learn what’s safe and what’s dangerous.

item.title: Postcript to Donna's Summer (Perhaps Tomorrow)
item.description: As I lay me down to sleep None could keep mine eyes from weep Except one small, distant hope Which saves me from that self-inflicted rope Perhaps, perhaps tomorrow will be the day When all my fear, and weeping, and sins are taken away So with a start I prattle about my miserable and wretched hovel Strewn here and there, chairs and tables overturned, hurrying to find that shovel With which I march to Juno for to dredge him abreast The man with whom I’ll walk before the throne, damned the rest Perhaps, perhaps tomorrow will be the day When all my fear, and weeping, and sins are taken away On that climb I’ll gaze with him upon the throng-ed score And our weeping for them will be the sweeping river which them keeps from the ajar-ed door Our boundless pity will be that which plunges the vast multitude down below On my knees for it the Lord I’ll beg for mercy, that what I did not know Perhaps, perhaps tomorrow will be the day When all my fear, and weeping, and sins are taken away But wait!

item.title: The Amputee
item.description: It’s something like losing your leg; So you must learn to walk without it. And it gets to a point where grief is of no use— A one legged man you are. It makes little difference to the truth; Besides, nothing can be done. But there are still those nights, Just before sleep, When you hope, Maybe even believe, That the miracle will be you. You’ll wake with firm foot And run in ecstasy to the kitchen Or the living room Or porch, To holler: “Hallelujah!

item.title: Of Pondering While You're Making a Sandwhich or Whatever
item.description: Whereof your thoughts when discovering you ran, In begging to end in circles again? Whenceforth you came indeed there you shall go; Wherefrom the soul is made we cannot know. And what would become of the Holy Saw? That is, what was once seen, now not at all, or the Holy Aurai Voir.

item.title: Who but Satan as The Internalized Gaze of The Other? (The Big One)
item.description: When, when he snubbed his nose at me Oh, how I bristled with delight. Nothing but evil could he be who took such pleasure in my plight. It was already known, the thought which bore its way into his mind. Serreptitious there, demon bought Solely for pleasure of its kind. But when the dog steals all the food Or when a child, denied, does cry, ‘Twas by a Spinozistic mode Those barbaric desires fly Into the poor and ill-restrained mechanical animal mind.

item.title: For Mao, On his Birthday
item.description: And there, in the dementiatic years of the 19th century The faintest natal nascence of the second kingdom was born in the middle of the middle. Poor Hong Xiuquan smiled in his tomb (of which there was none. More like ashes Dispirate, stirring). God is funny like that, to send his direct message through failure to beget another, indeed more confused, and yet, in contradiction, closer to enacting the truth.

item.title: For Jesus, On His Birthday
item.description: I was 6 years in the desert Self-exiled, by my own power. All gold once found then became dirt Heart-housed demons them they showered. There, whencefrom buried to my neck Came forth my savior with eyes kind Not as knight, me to pull from wreck, But sickle-celled black man, lame, blind. Snow from his nose poured on my head- “My poor child destroyed in his self, Foolish to think that you are dead Undying light offers his help.

item.title: Transluscent
item.description: I miss that little boy There were days when he cried and screamed But there are days when I do that too And I think he liked me - They were all calling for me to come back I was looking at pictures today They exist like beacons in a haze But the fog is too thick- Nothing is illuminated When was this? Who am I? Your smile is so bright there and I’ll never see it again nor remember how it was conjured in the first place To you, I must be a corpse with a death mask- And some wretched animating force moving me- And you were fooled to think this dead alive But perhaps by this power it was- and so it will I dug it all up today- and I’m sorry it was a demon in me, or something But even he could grow weary, and I often tucked him in with a glass of warm milk so we could be left alone.

item.title: On 3 Napkins in 1922 Carolina Coffee Shop
item.description: N.1 If all was light, we wouldn’t be able to see. I will go where I am led and through this giving thanks, may I be brought into what I would always become, and may my heart quicken in gladness at the thought of doing it again. N.2 If it’s true that the two primary emotions are fear and love, and that they are mutually exclusive, Then maybe FDR did nothing wrong, and to be afraid is to let the evil of the world enter your heart.

item.title: For James, and the PSR
item.description: A swift flick, swerve Placed us here In this grey-washed atrium watching television on the floor- they gave us nowhere to sit. Even in that moment I felt a strange lilt in my heart. Two bulls: dumb, headstrong, naive, smug, stubborn, and born with a recalcitrant need to be known made use of, and loved. Oceans in our eyes and rainforests in our hearts. Besides that, nothing in common. But still, you saw me smile and wheeled or wobbled over to attend to me.

item.title: Dec. 1
item.description: Like the creek happens to run with automobile traffic (Though they are at best enemies) so too, if you find yourself amongst the 7 foilaged trees in the heart of winter, likely without your rosary, The Beam comes around the bend And the tic turns your head To meet its gaze feeling as steam Screaming, you’ll kneel. eventually, prostrate, Ants will crawl up your nose And the orchestra will appear held there, supplicant They’ll play and you will cry, And as the intermission starts, while the conductor and the concert master shake hands, smiling towards a thunderous applause with no eyes, a car will fly off of Fordham Blvd.

item.title: Untitled
item.description: He was taken Lifted into the sky And was replaced with a copy The copy looked and sounded like him and kept up the ruse for awhile sweet + tender, delicate like a lily in the cold grew legs and ran to the top of the mountain, and threw itself off tumbled down holes in leaves Flowers left in disarray all behind for the hooves of bulls to later trample as they tried in vain to pick them up with their teeth, Lucky ones digested once he grabbed her by the hair, led her outside to shrieks + hollers a crowd formed Booing and gnashing teeth she was gnashed in turn and so the choir found themselves too gnashed at once all together in inexplicable violence that night they took the copy back and the original was returned with memories formed by the bubbling of Alka-Seltzer in stomach acid And as it bubbled, his hands grew to the size of stones, whence he had to drag forever

item.title: Vive le platonisme! Or, Funeral for A Luna Moth
item.description: If beauty has one immutible, intersubjective quality, is is transience. Like a lightning bolt from above, it flashes for but an instance in the grand scheme of things, and then it is gone… On Friday, I passed it in its sublimity. Halted in my tracks as if it were a wall. On Monday, in its place was death, decay, disgust, dread. I covered my mouth and ran just to trip and fall, to lie there, in that salinity, prostrate, for some time.

item.title: Sleepy
item.description: Oft I come so sleepy, E’en when mine eyes are weepy. Visit me in my dream so we can play And dream this other dream away.

item.title: Doodoo on a shoe
item.description: Old and weathered, Muddy ground giving way, Truths held as fact once proven otherwise, Horde of gold into dirt, Dirt into gold Spat upon, Cast out, Shat upon, Beaten, Abused, Objectified, Internalized, No water, no sun, New moon, no light, Rock, wind, debris; Where else but the navel with your sight?

item.title: What's It Like to Have Sex? (Against The Political Impositions of Dogmatic Natural Science)
item.description: The year is 202X, and alien life has finally found its way to Earth. These Alien beings are far more technologically advanced than us humans. In a matter of months, they teach us what would have taken centuries to discover: travel at the speed of light, among other things. These Aliens reproduce sexually, just like us. However, they go about it by means of external fertilization—the female lays her eggs in a location where, later, a male will fertilize them.

item.title: Thanatos
item.description: Slow it up speed it up! Like the derivative of a circle, Like a sin wave, Like the sublime and gorgeous Hills of the North Carolina piedmont. I want to feel that incline. I want to roll my body down, But this is not enough. I can’t go back up once I’m in the valley; Physics don’t work that way. And I’m left on my back With eyes towards the sky.

item.title: Untitled
item.description: Awoken from slumber and feeling the tension of the moment par coup, I flew to the archives, meticulously kept but thus far unread. These records changed me; One realizes one can’t let go of things one has said. Forsooth, the voices of the pages have been whispering to my unconscious, And at last question meets answer. I’d been using a crutch to stand; One outgrows such things. And yet the memories circle me as vultures; I can’t run from the easeness of tender voices, heartbeats, gazes.

The doctor recommended things like Clonazepam, Ambien, &c., but I thought I would much rather have something natural. So, I began to take melatonin supplements. item.title: Friday, September 9th, 2022
item.description: 1882: Nietzsche tears through the heavenly veil to find the Body of God, dead for 300 years. The corpse was rotting; maggot demons crawled through all His divine orifices, and the blood from the wound made centuries ago continued to gush forth, invisible to the naked eye, pouring like a monsoon on the realm of the demiurge, drowning all of humanity in ordained monadity. C. 50: The remaining druids secretly gather in the Scottish Hills to perform a final ritual.

item.title: Fragment 1
item.description: Then was reckoning, In the still and hollow night We saw stray cats and hooting owls, And from the chords of your guitar A seismic force shook the world. Buildings burned; people screamed; regimes collapsed. The smell of blood + fire took my nostrils. I fell on my broken knees. A brick split upon my head. Ash clouded my eyes. The unanimous groans of a condemned world Could not drown your voice.
